content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Find the ArXiv Blog on the ArXiv website and summarize the content of its latest article.  Please interact with https://arxiv.org/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current view of the ArXiv homepage does not show any direct link to the "ArXiv Blog." To locate the blog, I need to look for possible navigation menus, footers, or additional links that might not be visible in the initial viewport. Scrolling down may reveal a link to the blog or other informational pages commonly found at the bottom of academic or organizational websites.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current viewport remains focused on the listing of subject areas (Physics, Mathematics, Computer Science, etc.) without revealing any primary navigation menus, footer links, or informational pages such as "Blog." The blog link, if available, is likely further down the homepage, possibly in the page footer or an informational section.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The page continues to list academic categories without surfacing navigation to the ArXiv Blog. The footer or additional informational links are likely further down the homepage, so more scrolling is necessary to find the blog link.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.25
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "About arXiv" section is now visible, listing links such as "General information," "How to Submit to arXiv," "Membership & Giving," and "Who We Are," but none clearly mention a "Blog." The main footer includes legal, help, and status links, but does not directly mention a blog either. "General information" in section [29] might include further navigation or links to the blog.
Action: Click [29]
Confidence: 0.7
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I am now in the "Submission Guidelines" page, which is not relevant to finding the ArXiv Blog. There is a search input box at [3] in the top menu. Using the search box to look for "blog" or "arxiv blog" is likely the most efficient way to locate the ArXiv Blog on this site.
Action: Type [3]; blog
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.35
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search for "blog" led to the "Trackbacks" page, which is related to blog functions referencing arXiv papers, but does not offer access to the official ArXiv Blog. There is no evidence of a blog link here. I need to try searching for "arxiv blog" more specifically via the search box.
Action: Type [3]; arxiv blog
Confidence: 0.8
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search brought up an "About arXiv" informational page, with a menu on the left (News, Funding & Governance, Membership & Giving, Who We Are) but nothing directly referencing a blog. The "News" section [5] may contain updates or a link to an official blog if one exists.
Action: Click [5]
Confidence: 0.7
Completion: 0.45
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "arXiv Blog" link is now visible under the "News" section. Clicking this will likely lead to the official ArXiv Blog, where I can look for the latest article to summarize.
Action: Click [9]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.7

content:
Thought: The full content of the latest ArXiv Blog article is now visible. It details a scheduled maintenance for arXiv.org, the expected downtime, affected functions (logins, submissions), and advises authors to plan accordingly. The article also provides a link for updates and notes the maintenance is expected to take about two hours.
Action: ANSWER; The latest article on the ArXiv Blog is titled "Attention Authors: Upcoming Scheduled Maintenance to arxiv.org," published on September 16, 2025. It announces that arxiv.org will undergo scheduled maintenance on September 17th, 2025, between 7AM and 9AM EDT. During this period, while browsing, viewing, and searching papers will still be possible, all functions requiring a login (such as submissions, account management, and endorsements) will be disabled. Authors are advised that they will not be able to log in or submit papers during this time and should plan their submissions accordingly. The maintenance is expected to take two hours, and the blog provides a link (https://status.arxiv.org) for real-time status updates.
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 1.0
token: : ANSWER; The latest article on the ArXiv Blog is titled "Attention Authors: Upcoming Scheduled Maintenance to arxiv.org," published on September 16, 2025. It announces that arxiv.org will undergo scheduled maintenance on September 17th, 2025, between 7AM and 9AM EDT. During this period, while browsing, viewing, and searching papers will still be possible, all functions requiring a login (such as submissions, account management, and endorsements) will be disabled. Authors are advised that they will not be able to log in or submit papers during this time and should plan their submissions accordingly. The maintenance is expected to take two hours, and the blog provides a link (https://status.arxiv.org) for real-time status updates
